comments.commentBody:
The illusion of independence shattered by the hand of digital interference.

For many in our age of digital apps, we believe that we can connect to anyone effortless and that we are equal peers in the world of opportunity to conduct our personal lives. Uber's Greyball program shows us that this is an illusion or worse a delusion.

Like so many recent disclosures, Big Data can be deployed to draw connections. The pattern allowed Uber to present normality to users while surveilled. The ruse includes showing ghost cars to deceive. All of this against a background of tracking the source of the digital devices and payment mechanism to create a Greyball marked profile.

Readers must be aware that so many digital apps can do the same, and that public APIs make it possible for more than just the company itself from profiling users. There is no disappearing data. There are no anonymous activities; everything is building a digital dossier on everyone online.

If you are not paying for digital services, you are the product. Now you know what is being sold, your freedom.

And what do you do for a living? Is your industry protected in some way against competition by regulation? Spoiler Alert: Yes, it is.  From child labor laws to fraud law to OSHA, we as a society enact regulations that require businesses to limit their behavior in various ways.  Yes, the taxi industry was inefficient, and deserved more competition, but giving Uber carte blanche to violate the regulatory scheme governing hired cars, then turning a blind eye when it is revealed that they engaged in an ongoing, intentional conspiracy to evade law enforcement, is not the way to facilitate competition in a society dependent on the rule of law.

Wow, that was pretty lame analogy.  An addict is under the influence when he buys a drug, which prevents him from making a free choice.  This is hardly true for rider.  An addict is killing himself by doing drugs, whereas a rider is getting a valuable service.  By your logic, government could interfere int he free exchange of goods and services between any individual by claiming it's ok to prevent a drug addict from buying a drug.

Last year while in San Diego I was in Chula Vista and needed a ride back to the city. I set up an account with Uber but when after submitting a request for ride from the part of Chula Vista I was visiting the driver responding to my request initially provided their information then responded back several minutes later to submit another request for a ride.

At that time since it was an early Sunday morning, I thought the driver rather stay in bed then provide the service they signed up for, but now after reading these reports, I now question if any of Uber's program's "black listed" the area I was in at that time based on the type of service I requested.

I wish Uber would spend as much time on training drivers as they allegedly do on thwarting local government. On a recent trip from the airport to my home in Seattle a wrong turn landed us in an abandoned warehouse area at night and when I asked to return to the main road the driver kept insisting he was following GPS, despite the fact that we were going deeper and deeper into a maze of empty buildings. It wasn't until I raised my voice and told him he was making me uncomfortable that he stopped the car then threatened to leave me there. He then threatened to take me back to the airport. He seemed entirely unprepared for a situation when GPS malfunctions and his answer was to lash out at a very frightened passenger. I tried to remain calm and talked him into following my directions home but he was clearly enraged to have to take directions from a passenger, and I got the clear sense he wasn't too happy taking orders from a woman. Some very basic training in navigation, customer service and crisis situations would go a long way, but it's clear from the string of recent internal crisis that customers and employees are last on Uber's list of priorities. Goodbye Uber.

A driver told me that Uber does not supply its drivers with GPS's. As a consequence, the drivers buy and use the very cheapest such equipment. No wonder your driver got lost, using his five-buck GPS!

And no wonder that waiting for Uber is no different from waiting for a taxicab: add fifteen minutes to whatever wait the dispatcher gives you.

this is genuinely surprising and it sure explains a lot about my situation. it also speaks so clearly to the utter lack of concern for customer and driver safety by uber. among my friends, ranging from age 30-45, we have all deleted the uber app recently based on bad experiences, ranging from lost drivers to surge pricing, the near constant stream of negative press, and especially for their treatment of women.  the CEO"s continued questionable conduct underscores the lack of real leadership needed to guide a maturing company out of their frat house haze and into a more evolved organization. it's pretty clear that it's time for Kalanick to move along.

Potential riders are checked to see if they make the list of undesirables (starting with cops and public servants), and if so, they won't offer services to them. In order to find potential prosecutors or competitors, they need to check everyone's credit card and social media profiles.  How many people would use this service if they knew this is how they operated?  This is legal only because laws and court rulings haven't caught up to its practices.

The sad excuse that taxi company owners simply bribe public officials is growing thin, but some who have never bothered to delve into the whys and wherefores will continue this knee jerk reaction.

The common thread is security through background checks. Checking the local criminal files and running a 7-year check is much like FICO and your credit report. You may not like the looks of your taxi driver or the business that hires them, but when they have passed the 10-year criminal records background check and their fingerprints are run through the national records system, you may feel a bit more secure.

In my area, we have had some cab drivers robbed, shot, but it seems to be the private drivers who end up committing crimes against their fares. Not myth or bar talk - simple facts.

A small minority of people hate Uber. Sorry about your business, but nobody cried for the candlestick makers when the light bulb was invented and the taxi industry didn't lose any tears over me when I used to wait 90 minutes for a cab in the cold . Sorry, ride sharing is the wave of the future. 3 cheers for Uber using technology to avoid politics

I'm a liberal (not sure what political affiliation has to do with it, though) and have never used Uber or any other ride service, just official taxis. Taking a taxi is like reading a real book...the pleasure is in the tactile experience. I have never understood the need to jump on the latest bandwagon just for the sake of being uber "cool". It's taxis all the way for me.

Uber drivers can earn $500 per week. I know from experience and did it several times. Uber shafted me which is why I no longer look for the surges. On Christmas Eve, my account was deactivated. Merry Christmas, a lump of Uber in your stocking.

Logic, intuition and luck, it’s like fishing. Know where to go and when to park it, don’t drive around wasting gas. The ping will come. After finishing a fare, know where to go next. You never know where a passenger is going: the airport is best.

http://napoleonlive.info/what-you-think/uber-adventures/

"Uber drivers can earn $500 per week."

That's chickenfeed. I make more than that as a retiree. Also, there's an infinite distance between "_can_ earn" and "_do_ earn."
Yes, let's keep the same worn out, overpriced, often unavailable taxi monopoly sanctioned by local governments who extract fees from the riding public. Good call!

A minor point maybe, but what has always bothered me is the talk about "ride sharing". It has nothing to do with ride sharing. It's a billion-dollar corporation that has figured out a new way to hire people, but those drivers aren't "sharing" their cars any more than a conventional taxi driver is sharing the taxi with you.
It seems like social media could be used for a real ride sharing program - like you used to find on college bulletin boards, and maybe still do. But one sign that that was happening would be, nobody would be making a billion dollars from it.
Blah blahcar is a real ride sharing app that youth in Europe have been using for years. Nobody makes money so it doesn't exist here

I was riding in a Yellow Cab last night talking to the driver, and we got onto the subject of Uber, and I observed that many Uber's I've taken in Seattle, especially in the evening, smell strongly of cologne, or something like cologne.  The driver said it was because so many Uber drivers in Seattle smoke weed while on their shifts, and are using air freshener to disguise the smell.  I don't know if this is true, but it sounds plausible.  Either way, the ubiquitous cologne smell is the main reason I've been going back to Yellow Cab, which doesn't seem to have the same problem here.
So Uber drivers smoke weed but taxi drivers don't?  Ri-ight.
The infrastructure should be paid for by the gasoline taxes the drivers pay.
Close them down. I feel for the hardworking taxi drivers who have paid big-time for their businesses and who follow the rules. Uber has always been totally unfair.
The cases are different because in the Uber case no one is harmed by the customer's using the product (except the competitor offering the same service - but then what's capitalism?)

What about easy-to-use mobile technology, customer convenience and clean, well maintained vehicles? When it comes to pirates, you the one parroting the bitter complaints of the entrenched taxi and limousine interests.

Magic,

I for one do not see the connection, and feel that most normal people would also fail to see a connection between Uber which offers a great service and unsafe water and food.

Uber helps keep drunk drivers off the road. Taxi companies are greedy and usually run by corrupt scalawags that do worse than the officials at Uber have allegedly done.
My first reaction to Grayball is disgust but then I think and say to myself how different is this than a radar detector? Maybe the answer is none and that radar detectors are just as problematic.

It's call innovation meathead.  Government regulations are a real problem but the NY Times presents it like government is infallible.  Honest people are pressured to do so-called llegal acts when in fact the government is for government's sake.  Can't stand Trump but on this issue he is 100% correct.

In California (and I'm pretty sure in all the US), Uber has a $1 million liability policy over all drivers.
So, no problem!
Well, I suppose that soccer mom, who drives all the other kids along with hers to that soccer practice should be regulated too, eh?

No, that's not getting it straight.
The taxi industry was corrupt to the core, propagated by bribes (ok, "contributions") to elected officials to attain monopolies or oligopolies, with dreadful service to customers to boot!
So, I'll take Uber ANY day of the week in any city I happen to be in (now I'm in Rio de Janeiro, and Uber is our primary means of transportation).
Proving once again that violating the law and having flexible morals is the path to success.
I've deleted the Uber app from my phone. I've only used the service once. We can vote with our wallets against economic bullying.
